choices.B: When the amount of memory allocated for the result cache is increased
choices.E: When the maximum amount of server result cache memory that can be used for a single result is set to 0.
choices.A: When a user fixes incorrect marks for a student, with an update to the MARKS table, and then executes the function in the same session
choices.C: When the function is executed in a session frequently with the same parameter value
choices.D: When the database administrator disables the result cache during ongoing application patching

questions.question_text:
You created a PL/SQL function with the RESULT_CACHE clause, which calculates a percentage of total marks for each student by querying the MARKS table.
Under which two circumstances will the cache for this function not be used and the function body be executed instead?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
AD is correct
AD is right

comments.content: My bad - A and D. In E -RESULT_CACHE_MAX_RESULT(Specifies the maximum amount of server result cache memory (in percent) that can be used for a single result. Valid values are between 1 and 100. The default value is 5%. You can set this parameter at the system or session level.) cannot be set to 0

discussion.content: A and E are correct

comments.content:
As per https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/server.111/b28320/initparams206.htm#REFRN10272: 
RESULT_CACHE_MAX_SIZE specifies the maximum amount of SGA memory (in bytes) that can be used by the Result Cache. Values of this parameter greater than 0 are rounded up to the next multiple of 32 KB. If the value of this parameter is 0, then the feature is disabled.

So it must be that A and E are correct, not A and D.
SOrry: answ -> A,D for how i said before

E is not correct because of "Valid values are between 1 and 100. The default value is 5%. You can set this parameter at the system or session level." ref "https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/TGDBA/tune_result_cache.htm" 

Correct : A,E

discussion.content: A and D are correct. Setting parameter RESULT_CACHE_MAX_RESULT to 0 does not disable result caching. Changing table content triggers oracle to invalidate cach entries.

comments.content: I think because is not only memorize the answer but search the documentation

discussion.content: BC, not BD. Why are there so many errors in the answers?

Selected Answer: BC
BC is correct
B and C

questions.question_text:
Refer to the Exhibit.
//IMG//

Examine this procedure created in a session where PLSQL_OPTIMIZE_LEVEL =2:
//IMG//

PL/SQL tracing in enabled in a user session using this command:
EXEC DBMS_TRACE.SET_PLSQL_TRACE (DBMS_TRACE.TRACE_ENABLED_LINES)
The procedure is executed using this command:

EXEC PRC_1 -
Examine the exhibit for the content of the PLSQL_TRACE_EVENTS table.
Why is tracing excluded from the PLSQL_TRACE_EVENTS table?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct, forget E
B is right
Only B is correct answer.

choices.C: Tracing is not enabled with the TRACE_ENABLED_CALLS option.
choices.E: Tracing will be enabled only for the second execution of PRC_1.
choices.A: DBMS_TRACE.TRACE_ENABLED_LINES traces only exceptions in subprograms.
choices.B: PRC_1 is not compiled with debugging information.
choices.D: PRC_1 is compiled with the default AUTHID DEFINER clause.

choices.E: When you change an editioned object, all of its dependents remain valid.
choices.B: EBR does not let you upgrade the database components of an application while in use.
choices.A: There is no default edition defined in the database.
choices.C: You never use EBR to copy the database objects and redefine the copied objects in isolation.

discussion.content: Correct answers are D and F according to the linked reference.

Editions are nonschema objects; as such, they do not have owners. Editions are created in a single namespace, and multiple editions can coexist in the database. Tables are always noneditioned objects.

Selected Answer: DF
Agreed with orakell
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/appdev.112/e41502/adfns_editions.htm#ADFNS0201

choices.B: FOR indx IN 1_list. COUNT .. -1 LOOP DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE (indx | | | | 1_list (indx)); END LOOP;

choices.C: FOR indx IN -1 .. 1_list.LIMIT LOOP DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE (indx | | | | 1_list (indx) ); END LOOP;
